description: From Middle English breche, from Old English brēċ, from Proto-Germanic *brōkiz pl, from Proto-Germanic *brōks (“clothing for loins and thighs”). Cognate with Dutch broek, Alemannic German Bruech, Swedish brok.

entries.meaning: (obstetrics) Born, or having been born, breech.
(obstetrics, of birth) With the hips coming out before the head.
(historical, now only in the plural) A garment whose purpose is to cover or clothe the buttocks. [from 11th c.]
(now rare) The buttocks or backside. [from 16th c.]
examples: And he made a woman for playing the whore, sit upon a great stone, on her bare breech twenty-foure houres, onely with corne and water, every three dayes, till nine dayes were past  […]

entries.meaning: (firearms) The part of a cannon or other firearm behind the chamber. [from 16th c.]
(nautical) The external angle of knee timber, the inside of which is called the throat.

verbs.description: breech (third-person singular simple present breeches, present participle breeching, simple past and past participle breeched)

entries.meaning: (dated, transitive) To dress in breeches. (especially) To dress a boy in breeches or trousers for the first time (the breeching ceremony).
examples: […]  it occurred before I was breeched, and I was breeched at three years and a quarter old;

entries.meaning: (dated, transitive) To beat or spank on the buttocks.
(transitive) To fit or furnish with a breech.
(poetic, transitive, obsolete) To cover as if with breeches.
